snippet: Most members of a 20-piece band that plays regularly in Sheepshead Bay learned jazz clandestinely in Soviet-era Russia, where the authorities were suspicious of people interested in American culture.
abstract: Group of Russian jazz musicians who immigrated to United States in 1980s gather regularly in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, basement to rehearse; most were classically trained at Russian conservatories but had to learn jazz privately, in secret jam sessions or by acquiring recordings through friends or black market because government considered jazz music American propaganda.
lead_paragraph: Most members of a 20-piece band that plays regularly in Sheepshead Bay learned jazz clandestinely in Soviet-era Russia, where the authorities were suspicious of people interested in American culture.

headline.main: In a Brooklyn Basement, Jazz With a Russian Accent
headline.print_headline: In a Brooklyn Basement, Jazz With a Russian Accent
